subject: Ethics
title: Supply Chain Responsibility
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Supply Chain Responsibility.

hook.text: Your $5 t-shirt was made by someone earning $3 a day. The brand says it's not their factory, not their problem.

buildup.text: Global supply chains stretch across dozens of countries, subcontractors, and sub-subcontractors.

discovery.text: The 2013 Rana Plaza collapse in Bangladesh killed 1,134 garment workers. Major Western brands sourced there.

twist.text: Companies claimed ignoranceâ€”but their auditors had flagged the building's cracks months earlier.

climax.text: Are brands responsible for conditions ten layers deep in their supply chain? Legally, often no. Ethically?

punchline.text: You can outsource labor. You can't outsource responsibility.

quiz.question: What did the Rana Plaza collapse reveal about global supply chains?
options: Western brands had no connection to Bangladeshi factories
Brands sourced from unsafe factories despite audit warnings
Supply chain conditions had improved dramatically by 2013
